newsitem.title: UK: INTERVIEW - RMC sees German pressure into 1997.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - RMC sees German pressure into 1997.

text.p: British building materials giant RMC Group, which reported a steep first-half loss earlier on Thursday, warned that German sales pressure could continue into 1997, although the second half will show some improvement.

In an interview with Reuters, chief executive Peter Young said: "In Germany we would not expect the volumes in the second half to be as badly down as in the first half. But I don't want to be too optimistic. There may be a slight decline in volumes of one or two percentage points (in 1997)."
The German market is critical to RMC's fortunes. In 1995 Germany accounted for around 40 percent of profits and sales for the group.
But this year German sales have fallen sharply, hit by bad weather conditions and weak demand as the government tightens its fiscal stance.

Young said the UK housing market pick-up was just beginning to feed through to the new house sector, though he tempered his optimism by saying: "It will not be a bonanza. But there will be some improvement." On the French outlook, Young said it would "remain at the bottom".
RMC reported a a 26.5 percent slump in half-year pretax profits to 95.8 million stg, which Young said was in line with analysts' expectations after the spring profit warning.
Turnover slid five percent to 2.11 billion stg, but the dividend rose five percent to 7.8 pence.
The group said the second-half results were likely to be more satisfactory, but warned that the full year figures would not match the record levels enjoyed in 1995.
